messageBody:
The following was written on February 25, 2002. I had intended to work
some more on it before posting
it, but I have not found the time. Since we are getting so many posts
on remapping the keyboard and
ways to go about that, I felt I should get my two cents in. I am not
sure if my suggestion as set out
below of using "d," "f," "j," and "k" as "function" keys causing the
other keys to alter their output would
be feasible. I had the impression from reading some of the earlier
posts that it would be, but now I am
not so sure.

Paige


Jon:

I appreciate your response which sheds light on the subject of
remapping Jerome. I
have no experience at this and was blissfully ignorant of the
contortions people using
computers with other languages were having to deal with, but you have
got me thinking
about it. I also had not considered the needs of an individual who
types in QS as
part of his job and who needs to develop as much speed as a typist in
roman. Of
course, we do not have anyone in that position now, but it makes
sense if we go to the
trouble of remaping Jerome that we should make the new keyboard as
efficient as
possible. By the way, you are the only person I have actually
communicated with that
has tried Dvorak. My knowledge about it was totally academic.


After considering your post, I have attached in wordpad format a
proposed remapping of
Jerome, which I believe is much more logical than what we have now
and adopts some of
your suggestions. The remainder of this post explains my thinking
regarding this
remapping.

It had not occurred to me to use another key (rather than "shift")
for the purpose of
producing all the letters needed for QS. I guess I was still
thinking along
typewriter lines. (I did know that each key combination produces a
binary code which
is at some point translated by (I assume a driver) into the
appropriate character for
the output.) It makes sense that it would be slightly faster to
utilize a letter on
the home row rather than the "shift" key to specify an alternate
character for a
particular key since it eliminates the need to move a finger off the
home row.

In effect what we require is similar to a function key on a
scientific calculator,
which after it is activated, causes the regular keys to return a
different output
after activation than their default output. I have a scientific
calculator which uses
two separate function keys which permits each regular key to serve
three different
functions.

Since there are fifteen (15) vowels in the QS alphabet and five (5)
in the roman
alphabet, it seems to make sense for each roman vowel to be mapped to
three (3)
different vowels in QS. Therefore, we need to map two function keys
for the left hand
and two function keys for the right hand just as we now have a right
and left shift
key. I propose that the left hand function keys be "f" and "d", and
the right hand
function keys be "j" and "k." This uses the forefinger and index
finger of each hand
which for the average person are probably the two strongest and agile
fingers on each
hand.

I have mapped a, e, i, o and u with three QS vowels each. The
primary key by itself
returns the long vowel. The primary key plus the opposite hand's
forefinger, i.e. "f"
or "j" returns the short vowel, and the primary key plus the opposite
hand's index
finger, i.e. "d" or "k" returns the final vowel, which is an
additional vowel
generally associated with the roman vowel with the exception of the
third vowel on the
"i" key. (I guess no system is perfect.) Since all QS vowels are
mapped to the
standard five roman vowels, they should be fairly easy to learn.

Again, for ease of learning, I placed the half-letters on the same
keys as their
primary letters, and they are activated by pressing the forefinger of
the opposite
hand at the same time. "Q" remained unused, and it made sense to map
it to wholewheat
and half-wholewheat as it was next to "W".

"X" remained unused so I mapped the two QS equivalents to that key.
Now you can keep
both of them, Jon. I assume the "ks" should be the primary key, and
the "gs" would be
the secondary key obtained by simultaneous pressing of the opposite
hand forefinger,
i.e. "j." I mapped alternate "No" to the "n" key, again with the
secondary function
obtained by hitting it with "f". I mapped "Inkling" as the primary
key for "c", and
the secondary is the alternate form of "Up". The namer dot I mapped
to the secondary
position for "m". This puts it next to the comma which seemed
appropriate.

This covers everything except the following: sh, ch, zh, th, dh and
the alternate
form "Other". I followed your suggestion and mapped them as two
letter combinations.
"Other" I mapped to "xh".

Check out the attached file with its chart, and let me know your
thoughts on this. I
believe it will be much easier to learn than what we have had so far.

Paige
